data.title: Markdown previewing for code blocks breaks when 1st line is square bracket

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
A picture speaks a thousand words. First screenshot, Markdown previewing is incorrect and ordered numbering is subsequently broken also as a result of the first line of the code starting with an open square bracket. When the open square bracket is replaced with another character (a number 1 in the second screenshot), the preview works fine.
![markdown preview with square bracket](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15855642/12009586/bbef16a2-ac76-11e5-8858-3833369d4871.png)
![markdown preview with another char](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15855642/12009588/c0483c2e-ac76-11e5-8cda-846bf9f1022c.png)

data.title: ${file} variable should change when active editor pane switches to a different file
data.body:
It appears that the `${file}` variable can be used in `launch.json` configurations to determine the "program" to be run when the user starts the debugger.  A couple users of the PowerShell extension have discovered that this variable will have the file path of the first opened file in the workspace.  However, if they switch active files this variable does not change, meaning that the debugger will always run that first file.  See more discussion here:

https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/commit/a613d5eafa2f014ce0b2b5b857eb60d4e6d11fb8

It would be nice if this variable got updated dynamically so that the user can run the debugger against the currently active file without having to manually edit their `launch.json` file each time.  This is a pretty common practice when developing PowerShell scripts.

data.title: Provide an option to insert a final newline
data.body: Something similar to  `insert_final_newline = true`.

data.title: [Typescript React] tsconfig.json is ignored
data.body:
I have added the "jsx" flag to "compilerOptions", in the tsconfig.json file, at the root of the project directory:

`tsconfig.json` :

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "jsx": "react",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "noImplicitAny": false,
        "removeComments": true,
        "preserveConstEnums": true,
        "outDir": "dist",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "target": "es5"
    },
    "files": [
        "ABC.tsx"
    ]
}
```

Yet building the app via VSCode Command-Shift-B ignores these settings, and the output is:

```
ABC.tsx(14,12): error TS17004: Cannot use JSX unless the '--jsx' flag is provided.
ABC.tsx(18,17): error TS17004: Cannot use JSX unless the '--jsx' flag is provided.
```

I have checked by compiling directly via the command line such as:
`tsc --jsx react ABC.tsx` 
and it works fine there.

It seems that all the configs in the tsconfig.json file are being ignored.

Specs:
tsc: message TS6029: Version 1.7.5
VSCode: 0.10.6
OSX 10.11

data.title: [css] @namespace is not syntax highlighted

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Works correctly in the parser for linting and in Intellisense, but isn't syntax highlighted as missing from css.plist

![screen shot 2015-12-26 at 2 37 41 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/465069/12006056/9bc57176-ab79-11e5-8cd7-bc98db523dff.png)

Syntax should be:

 namespace
    : NAMESPACE_SYM S\* [namespace_prefix S_]? [STRING|URI] S_ ';' S*
    ;
  namespace_prefix
    : IDENT
    ;

My knowledge of the syntax of css.plist and regexp isn't good enough at the moment to work out how to add the optional IDENT, as there is no predefined ident like there is for strings, etc. I know how to highlight the @namespace and string component though. 

I figure the IDENT should be coloured the same as @namespace as that is how the media type token is coloured for '@media media-type'

data.title: [CSS] Syntax highlighting no longer works for property keyword values and functions
data.body:
Before Dec update:

![screen shot 2015-12-25 at 7 54 16 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/465069/12005061/54abec08-ab41-11e5-8330-4ed4adae99a4.png)

After:

![screen shot 2015-12-25 at 7 54 42 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/465069/12005062/5a3ab38e-ab41-11e5-9457-034bb64b5284.png)

As you can see, while the property names are highlighted, the values are the same whether it is valid or not. The data is in the css.plist file, it is just not getting read, or the colour is no longer set, for whatever reason.

data.title: Detect Language Mode from Modeline Comment

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I use Vagrant a bit. The file `Vagrantfile` is extensionless and as a result is shown as plain text.  The file is actually a ruby script.  You can see it in the comments; something vim and vi support.

```
# -*- mode: ruby -*-
# vi: set ft=ruby :
Vagrant.configure(2) do |config|

end 
```

It would be extremely useful if VisualStudio Code could honor those settings and display the file in the correct language mode. It would even be better if other settings, like tab length etc could be honored. I'm assuming the latter will overwrite the workspace and user settings. 

Modeline magic
http://vim.wikia.com/wiki/Modeline_magic

data.title: How to configure IntelliSense in Visual Studio Code?
data.body:
How to configure IntelliSense in Visual Studio Code?

For example, lets consider the below code snippet.

``` js
'use strict';

import React from 'react';
import ReactDOMServer from 'react-dom/server';
```

I would like the IntelliSense to suggests the available methods on `React`, when I press `cmd + space` after typing `React.`.

Is that possible? If yes any pointer would be of great help.

**PS:**

I have already installed the `dependent modules` and updated the `package.json` and they are available at `./node_modules/`

---

_Raised it at [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33924317/how-to-configure-intellisense-in-visual-studio-code) a month ago._

data.title: Python loop syntax highlight.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In Python for loop, "in" should be syntax-highlighted. But it is just plain text. 

Example:

for list in lists:
    do_something(list)

"in" in code above should be syntax-highlighed, but it is not.

data.title: gulpfile.hygiene on Windows
data.body:
I'm using Windows with `core.autocrlf=true` which means that files in my working directory have CRLF line endings, but are converted to LF when I commit. But I can't commit because the hygiene check fails because it sees the CRLF endings.

I got around it by converting the file to just use LF, but is there a recommended workflow for Windows environments? Working entirely in LF might work but inevitably some tool won't like that. Maybe hygiene could skip the line ending check if `core.autocrlf=true`?
